name: Keema Naan
history: Keema Naan is a popular variety of naan, a classic Indian flatbread. It originated in the Indian subcontinent and is known for its rich and savory filling made from minced meat (keema), typically lamb or chicken, and a blend of spices.
description: Keema Naan is a stuffed naan bread filled with a flavorful mixture of minced meat, herbs, and spices. It's typically baked in a tandoor but can also be made on a stove. This naan is often enjoyed as a main dish or served with a side of curry.

ingredients.item: spices (garam masala, cumin powder, red chili powder)

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine flour, yeast or baking powder, sugar, and salt. Add milk, yogurt, and oil to form a soft dough. Knead well and let it rest for about 2 hours until it doubles in size.

instructions.title: Cook the Keema
instructions.description: In a pan, cook the minced meat with onions, green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, spices, and salt. Cook until the meat is well done. Stir in coriander leaves and set aside to cool.

instructions.title: Stuff and Shape the Naan
instructions.description: Divide the dough into balls. Roll each ball into a circle, place some keema filling in the center, and seal it. Roll it again gently into an oval shape.

instructions.title: Bake the Naan
instructions.description: Place the naan in a preheated tandoor or oven. Bake until puffed up and golden brown. Optionally, brush with butter or ghee.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Keema Naan hot, ideally with a side of yogurt or chutney.

tips: Ensure the keema is cooked until it's dry to prevent the naan from becoming soggy.
You can adjust the filling ingredients according to your preference.
variations: Add peas or potatoes to the keema for additional texture and flavor.
Experiment with different types of minced meat or even a vegetarian filling.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored for up to 1 day in the refrigerator.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container and reheat in the oven before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in the oven or on a tawa until warm.
presentationTips: Serve on a traditional Indian platter with accompaniments like mint chutney.
Garnish with a sprinkle of fresh coriander or a wedge of lemon.
